Overall, Isle of Dogs is a great change of pace compared to most movies. The plot of the film is satisfying, with dogs being casted away to Trash Island from Megasaki City due to a new disease and a corrupt office that has a biased against dogs. The story focuses on 12year old Atari who flies to Trash Island to find his bodyguard-dog, and tries to bring justice to what was once mans best friend. The positives of the movie is the the character development of the dogs throughout the story, and the background culture of the nation of Japan that influences the film. The negatives would be the character appeal of those who are against using the cure for the dogs. Overall, this movie deserves a 9/10 for great animation, and a satisfying plot about saving dogs as a man's best companion.

This movie isn't for children. So said another review. Not quite true. This movie is for the children in all of us. It is simple, complex, funny, sad, easily accessible and very difficult to grasp all at the same time. Subsequent viewings are recommended. Each will reveal a new layer, just like an onion but not nearly as sour.

Review title: I don't get the good reviews
Review_body: Oh my god it was boring! Where did all these people who gave it 8, 9 or 10 stars come from? I almost fell asleep in it! The story moved so slowly, was uninteresting and completely predictable. I thought it was going to be a cute film about dogs, it wasn't. NOT RECOMMENDED!!!

Review title: Unique and fun.....with a bit of a disappointing ending.
Review_body: Ending felt a bit like they had just written themselves into a corner.

I was very excited for this movie back in March when it hit limited release where I live. I drove an hour to see this movie and I loved it! I have since seen it 3 more times and it gets better everytime! Just from a technical view this is spectral achievment. But, the storytelling is on point in everyway. It is more political than some of Wes's other films but in my opinion it just adds to the story. It is rare that a movie has such a clear vision and Wes Anderson's is nesr perfect. I have 2 major complaints: first off, Tracy Walker feels very unnecessary. I understand why she is in the movie, but she really doesnt seem like she needs to be here. Also, any pans look unfocused to me primarily because everything is in focus and moving. They usually dont last long but everything moving in focus looks as if nothing is in focus. I highly reccomend this near masterpiece. See it as soon as you can!

First of all, do NOT take your or any children to see this movie, they would not get most of the jokes and would not appreciate the amount of work that has been put into this picture. Although it is a animated movie, IT IS NOT FOR CHILDREN.Right after the movie ended and credits started to roll down, I was speechless. I immediately wanted to watch it again. The plot was great, the animation detail technique was astonishing. The cinematography was dynamic.
This movie did not lose me for a second. There was nothing that bothered me a bit and 'cause of that, I give Isle of Dogs by Wes Anderson a 10/10.

Wes Anderson proves his newly-discovered talents for blending animation and storytelling, comedy and relevance, heart and humour in his second stop-motion picture. 20 human years into the future (not certain about dog years) a breakout of dog flue in the Japanese city of Negasaki has 'forced' the government to banish all dogs to Trash Island. There, the dogs form their own savage society until Atari (Kuyo Rankin) tumbles in in search of his dog.What is perhaps most wonderful about this film is the beauty of it. Each and every dog has been given equal care and effort in creation and each look is scruffy yet loveable. The audience therefore, cannot help but fall in love with each K-9 character they meet. Hearing the words 'Trash Island' used to describe the film's setting would usually be enough to put anyone off yet Anderson surprises audiences. The trash is colour correlated and arranged in such ways that resemble the beauties of modern society and bring a strange charm to the world of the film. A cave the leading dogs have built for themselves comes to mind; the whole thing built out of empty bottles of various colours. This makes it resemble a jewel cave or something even more wonderful. Such care in setting is accommodated by a carefully chosen cast. Actors such as Bryan Cranston, Jeff Goldblum and Tilda Swinton allow themselves just enough freedom to develop individual characters. We hardly have time to get to know anyone with the speed of the film, yet the independent quirks of each dog allow just enough life and wit to be given. Most of the humour derives from rather dark jokes bordering around animal cruelty and certain injustices in Japanese culture. An example being a chef preparing sushi dinner and, in the process, carving open the head of a still-alive crab. Another being the dogs gossiping about the miserable and suicidal way that one of their comrades lost his life. These quirks seem like Anderson's way of making small statements about human's powerful ability to be cruel to creatures we deem as less powerful than ourselves. After all, what's crueller than abandoning sick puppies on a dirty and disease-ridden island? Anderson still pays tribute to the culture he toys with by presenting Kabuki dances and having his human characters speak their native tongue. Their own injustices are still there however, and its evident the thesis he attempts to present about human nature.Of-course not all the jokes are this dark. Most of the humans in the film are presented as silly using fast-paced slapstick actions. Most of this humour derives from its own unexpectedness and thus, should not be spoiled in a review. The quirks balance out the darkness in the film and ensure that the audience keeps laughing and involved in the film. All other social statements aside, this is a tale about a dog's loyalty to his master. Watching the friendships develop between the dogs and Atari demonstrates this love and ties together all other themes explored. Ultimately, leaving audiences with a sense of hope as they leave the cinema. The only downside to the film is a somewhat abrupt and unrealistic ending. The ending does tie up loose ends yet gives everything to its main characters from basically nothing. Does this contribute to any morals or themes of the film? It'll need to be up to the audience to tell. Wes Anderson is famed and glorified for his strange and unique creative style. Isle of Dogs is perhaps his strangest and yet one of his best. With humour and flair, the film speaks up for those who cannot speak for themselves and ensures laughs from audiences pro-dog and not. Out of Five: 4 StarsDid you know: Jeff Goldblum recorded his lines over the phone due to scheduling conflicts with another film.

As a dog lover and anime-hater I expected to be less than impressed by this offering, despite the director's credentials. However, it proves that man's best friend (and their friends) speak a language that may be neither Japanese nor English, but one we all understand. Amazed by how universal and diverse this movie could appeal. Dogs love us maybe because we conditioned them to do so, but they are also smart. The only thing that stops me giving this a 10 is the slightly different animation and not the Japanese thing which I originally thought would lead to minus marks.

The detail that went into this film is just mind-blowing! The sets, script, score, and voice acting are all so perfectly in sync. The film as a whole is just daring enough to be amazing, without overdoing it and taking itself too seriously. Bryan Cranston, Jeff Goldblum, and Courtney B. Vance standout among an all around AMAZING cast. The sets are as aesthetically pleasing as it gets: detailed, colorful, themed, and thought-proving. The plot, as to be expected, is engaging and fun. If you liked Fantastic Mr. Fox, this film was made just for you. Definitely worth your valuable time!
One of the best movies I've ever seen! I Love dogs
From the different styles to the awesome characters, I loved everything...!

Review title: Awesome, epic, adventurous spirit, and hidden messages
Review_body: Wes Anderson has been able to craft a masterful beautiful story's from his creative imagination with amazing breathtaking soundtrack and unique deep messages.

Review title: One of the best stop animation film out there
Review_body: One of the best out there especially with the sushi sense the looking to good to be made one frame at a time
Beautiful, thoughtful, magical Film, full of character.

There's no obvious point of entry.But -- and I must say *this* -- the way he adds to the usual, anthropomorphized treatment of dogs (Anderson does) by incorporating more of their behavior (shaking, sneezing, scratching, scarfing, etc.) is *brilliant*.This is a great film, firing on all levels.Believe this.

My friend made me watch this movie four nights ago. I resisted but gave in and had no idea what I was in for. OMG ... i've now watched it at least twice a day since then. The visuals, humor, the perception from a dogs view, and the music, the music gets you. Go in with no expectations and enjoy the ride.
This was a really good movie. It wasn't your adverse typical cute dog movie, it had meaning. I loved it.
I was so impressed about this movie! I really liked the animation because it reminded me of Fantastic Mr. Fox!

I absolutely loved this film. The art was so good, music brilliant, great story, so creative, and funny. I can't wait to get a copy for home once it's available. I think it will reward multiple viewings.

Review title: I went for Wes Anderson and I got Wes Anderson
Review_body: I've just seen this movie at Berlinale and it is exactly what you would expect from Wes Anderson. I wasn't sure how he would do with a non-Western setting but he managed well.He keeps his unique style and it works very well with the futuristic, but still traditional Japanese art. It also incorporates some cartooning along with interesting ideas - the Japanese dialogue is not always translated and when it is, it's by interpreters or foreign exchange students. Anderson manages to merge his style with the Japanese and it works seamlessly.It's a very quirky film with an all too relatable story. I enjoyed the visuals more than the plot, I'll admit, but it was still a good movie, with the usual quick dialogues, jokes, strange characters - Tilda Swinton being the weirdest, no surprise there - and altogether it's a great experience.Without spoilers, if you like Wes Anderson, you will like this movie. If you don't, buckle up, because this is jam-packed with everything that is his style, the quirky music works now fused with Japanese, Bill Murray, Jeff Goldblum and the usual cast having very well fitting characters (watch out for the credits Anjelica Huston is there as a Mute Poodle) and the cinematography being interesting and stunning.P.S. It's still not a children's movie, don't let the format fool you.

I love the visuals of Wes Anderson movies. He is one of my favourite directors. The colors, the setup, the paintings, the alignments and silhouettes. Isle of dogs is no exception. But! This is a movie made by men for men. Lead and most supporting characters are male. Animals that usually have no sex are male. The owl is referred to as he, almost all the dogs have male voices. There are only three female dogs, first is the beautiful show dog, the second the motherly dog that instantly gets pregant and whos only role is to nurture, build a family and admire the male family dog, the third is the so-called oracle who only watches TV all day and stands next to the bigger, respected organising alpha male dog.Then there are three female human characters. One girl that actually says that she is in love with Atari although that contributes nothing to the story, the female scientist who can't manage her life without her male achiever colleague who commits suicide and the female translator who, well, at least works and does not talk about men and their superiority/manlihood all the time but also doesn't contribute anything to the progress of the movie other than commenting and translating to the audience.Wes Anderson knows better to write for stronger, more diverse roles. The actors/voices (Scarlett, Tolda, Greta - really?) know better to demand better female roles and dialogs. And the audience knows better not to vote 10 stars when it only has 0-star-female characters in it.

Review title: If you ready not to waist your time, sit down and watch!
Review_body: Three hours ago, I just did one of the best decision in my past year. I went to watch #IsleOfDogs. I surely recommend it to you too. One of the best-animated movies in past few years. Directed and written by #WesAnderson as well he directed #GrandBudapestHotel. It is amazingly written, with so much detail, humour will be acceptable to these kind of people who like something more than dumb and dumber, it is very creative and it's hard to blink because you don't want to miss a second in this movie from beginning to the end. So sit down and enjoy the originality of this movie and how strangely warm it makes you smile hour after the movie was finished.I am giving 10* of 10* on IMDb and it's already 8.2*.
I very good movie of a Japanese movie about an isle of dogs
Wes at his best! Beautiful picture, soundtrack, characters, rythm...

It's a production design, graphic delight. Difficult not to compare it to Fantastic Mr Fox and is no match for it. It has more dark than light. 
Some of the characters not given a lot of time to express themselves. 
Still an enjoyable film and will look forward to learning more about the behind the scenes.
So magical and loving,wonderfull story with great animations
I hated this movie. I didn't get the point at all.

If you say 'Isle of Dogs', it also sounds like 'I love dogs'. And this is how brilliant this movie is.
Alexandre Desplat's music is a perfect fit for the beautiful characters and extraordinary animation.
Super witty and hits a rhythm that keeps you sucked in. Characters and world design is incredible.
I'm usually hot and cold when it comes to Wes Anderson but this was in my top 5 of 2018

I would not consider myself a Wes Anderson fanatic like some people would, but I certainly do enjoy his films. In an era of big budget superhero movies dominating the box office, it is refreshing to see someone with such a unique vision continuing to thrive. His latest effort, Isle of Dogs, is no exception to his commitment of great film making. Anderson's style translates extremely well to this type of story; simple yet entertaining at its core. His technical precision, comedic timing, camera movement, and quick editing elevates a timeless plot into something truly captivating. The star of the show is the quality of the animation. This is Anderson's sophomore effort into the medium (the first being 2009's "Fantastic Mr. Fox") and he has yet again achieved something remarkable. His team's effort to make the animation look flawless absolutely translates to the screen while viewing this film. The voice acting for the most part is done well. While I take some issue with almost exclusively casting well know actors to play these characters, overall they did a good job. Bryan Cranston is the real standout here, as his gravely voice and intensity fits the character he is playing. He voices a dog named Chief and his character arc, as well as his relationship with the young protagonist, Atari, are the emotion core of the movie. Their dynamic has been seen before but is really well executed through the animation and voice performances. Despite these positives and my overall enjoyment of the movie, there are some negatives to the movie. The dialogue can very often fall into the cliche or hokey category which is not atypical for a Wes Anderson film. He writes his films purposely deadpan which is acceptable but this, however, causes some of the jokes to misfire or completely miss the mark and could be solved with a change in style. That being said, I did laugh a few times throughout the movie, with some of the visual gags being quite funny. There is a subplot involving a foreign exchange student character (played by Greta Gerwig) that I found to be distracting. Every time it cut to this character, I was just hoping it would return to the main characters as soon as possible. They are the real heart of the story. I also found some of the editing choices to be awkward, possibly relating to this being stop motion animation and hence, being more difficult to edit. It is possible, but I am by no means an expert in the field. I did overall enjoy the film despite is flaws in the writing, editing and overall simple story. The quality of the animation and the emotional core of the movie kept me engaged throughout the run time of the film and I would definitely like to see this again in theaters with some friends to gauge their reaction to the film. I would recommend the film to Wes Anderson fans, who will probably get the most enjoyment out of the film. The general audience I viewed the film with seemed to enjoy it so I would also give it a recommendation to the wider public as long as you keep an open mind to different styles of film making. Overall Rating: 7/10

Review title: Got what I expected, Great movie, Great animation, and Dogs.
Review_body:
Drove an hour to see this one and it was worth it! A bummer it did not have a wide release all at once, but gave us a new chance to experience a different theater. The plot is good and expands a bit more throughout the story past what you know from the trailer - but not to the point of confusion or thorough thought. 
 The animation and characters and scenery were amazing. I already want to watch it again since we had to sit front row so that made it hard to take in all the detail on the big screen being so close.
 I wouldnt bother bringing any kids under 13 or so, as it deserves the PG-13 rating. Some adult talk, a few swears, some blood and depiction of injuries, ect. 
However more important, this isnt a knee-slapping comedy kids movie. It has a good pace and I was never bored, but the pace may be just a bit too slow, and comedy lacking for young kids. However, adults will appreciate this film, especially if you have a thing for stop motion. 
 If you are a feminist or critical of cultural references, maybe dont bother as this movie shows people in their "typical" roles and one of the main heros is an American trying to sway the masses. I hate that I have to mention any of that...just enjoy the great movie!

Review title: Brilliant Piece of Art. Great movie for people who love little not excessive comedy and dogs
Review_body: Just watched it, and it's one of the best movie I have ever seen. With such a scarcity of claymation movies these days this movie comes in as a great addition - It's funny, it's cute, it shares a deep message, and overall a brilliant piece of art - the art style of this movie is unique, never seen something like this before.If you are a dog person, you are going to chuckle a lot at the small details with the dogs in this movie.Totally a must watch, and it's that one kind of movie that you would like to watch again and again because you never get enough of it!

Wonderful movie obviously written and directed by someone who really understands and appreciates dogs. The pacing and scene progression approximate a dog's point of view resulting in comic as well as poignant moments. The production's creativity makes it easy to stay engrossed to the very end.

With in the first few seconds I was already haveing a good time. Wes pulls off another entertaining animation. Each character definitely has there quirks and characteristics. All of wich are enjoyable, even the side characters and villains. Every member of the cast gives a solid performance. It's well paste and structured. Doesn't Direlle off too much in to any small points or subplots no time is wasted on any others stories other then the 3 or so main characters. The core of the story is quite simple, and the situation everyone else is in is well explained. At first I was a little frustrated there wasn't subtitles for the Japanese characters, but soon realized it doesn't matter. We're only given the necessary information. Any additional information could have distracted and/or confused me. The style of animation is pleasing to the eye, with its atension to detail, for even the shortest segments. Additionally the cartoonish style on the televisions add a funny component to the whole film.Stop animation almost always gets extra points in my book. With how much more care and craft, is put in to each and every frame. You can't help but appreciate the film, even with a less then Ideal story.Everything is accompanied by a intense and compelling musical score. That really brings you in to this world.
In short it's a fun and enjoyable film with a gently delivered message that isn't shoved down your throat.Would highly recommend to animation lovers.
Great story, great actors doing the voices, worth watching over and over.
Nice movie for all ages, with a good storyline and a profound message. Also fun to watch.

Review title: If you watch this movie, you'll feel like a dog with two tails =)
Review_body:
The recent stop-motion animated film of Wes Anderson (writer and director) offers us 110 minutes of sharp wit, touching moments and an unexceptional plot that is full of heartfel and warmth. The plot centres around a pack of sick dogs that are kept in quarantine in an area called Trash Island near Japan. A boy called Atari goes to that island trying to find and resue his dog Spots and he gets help from other outcast dogs. The boy's search inspires a group of dog lovers to fight against this government's measure and this group shows that the goverment is trying to hide something. The plot is gripping and quite entertaining.
The entire cast is superb and some the recognizable voices includes Bryan Cranston, Edward Norton, Bill Murray, Scarlett Johansson, Tilda Swinton, Bob Balaban, Greta Gerwig, and Yoko Ono. Apart from the plot and its fantastic cast, some highlight features of the "The Isle of Dogs" worth mentioning are the visual effects and the clash of cultures between the characters in the movie (Japanese vs English).
Overall, this film will have you laughing out loud and crying your eyes out at the same time. The enganging plot and effects make the movie work. I can't think of a better way to spend an evening than watching this film with yuor family or friends.

After The Grand Budapest Hotel, I thought that no film afterwards by the same director would be able to compete, but I was proved wrong when I went to see Anderson's latest movie. The animation style has certainly improved since his first stop motion feature, Fantastic Mr Fox, but Anderson's familiar and much loved directing traits remain. The cinematography is absolutely extraordinary, which is complimented by a range of quirky, funny and well developed characters- despite not being able to understand any of the Japanese characters, it is still easy to empathise and understand the motivations of these characters. The story, though not overly complex, is still intelligent and engaging.
The film may at first appear, especially from the trailers, to be a fun family jaunt in a quirky animation style, but within minutes it is established that relatively mature themes will be explored throughout, which they are, often with explicit detail. This, however, does not harm its availability to younger ages. 
I would thoroughly recommend this film to everyone and hope that none will miss this fantastic film.

This is cool to look at. Otherwise, leave it for Wes Anderson fanboys who can see no wrong in anything he does. It's got some tedious things like all the main characters are male dogs voiced by older men. And not particularly well. And the female dog is depicted as feminine and pretty and voiced by a young, attractive woman with a "#x22; voice. Yuck to that brand of anthropomorphism. It's the opposite of creative or cool. And a really petty criticism? The dog names are so basic and boring. This movie felt SO LONG too. I started checking the time only 35 mins in. However, the most disappointing thing is that the film seems written by people with no love or understanding of dogs. They're just annoying, unoriginal human characters that happen to be drawn as dogs. The stray dog Chief is especially tiresome, plus Bryan Cranston does not elicit any charm in the role. And the heavy-handed sociopolitical metaphors are just...sledgehammered in. It's no Animal Farm.

Like many of the other reviewers I was hyped to see this film purely because it was a Wes Anderson but I truly had my doubts about how he would pull it off. After leaving the cinema all I can say is WOW... Unlike anything I've ever seen before. There was still so many signature Wes elements but the way the Japanese setting was incorporated was something completely new which just blew me away. Exceptionally witty, heartwarming, and just all round awesome visual experience.

I've never reviewed a movie before! But this film was so delightful that I felt like I should give it a positive review! This has probably become my favorite Wes Anderson film yet. But I'll need to see it a couple more times before I can make that call. The timing in this film is impeccable. The humor has a perfect balance of cute and dark humor it's a weird mix. For a stop motion film it's so meticulous and detailed it's probably the first Stop motion film i've seen where i forgot I was watching a Stop motion film. It's also the perfect length I feel like a lot of stop motion films are short due to budgeting reasons this felt like it told the whole story and left you happy.
I was excited to see this considering all the great actors in it. I was very disappointed. It was boring, not funny and just plain dumb! What a waste of time

Review title: Ate mushrooms and couldn't have picked a better movie
Review_body: Man there was dogs running around and then they could talk. What a world. Great movie if you want your dog to talk and never get lost.

Review title: Very unique style, promissing start, underwhelmed by extremely basic storyline
Review_body:
I was excited to see this movie, it had overwhelmingly positive ratings and very interesting artistic style, and seemingly interesting and inspiring story.It all turned around in the first few minutes, the movie started to be driven by a very standard story, "good guy, bad guy" plot, with a slight twist. Way too much time was spent by movie trying to explain everything to you, feeling like a boring video game dialogue.
Maybe it wouldn't be half bad, if the story was presented in less obvious way, with more mystery.
It's too predictable for an adult, too much unnecessary "tutorials" about story for children. Feels like somebody tried too hard to make the movie widely understood, in result making it bland and uninspiring.
Great film, loved it. If you liked Fantastic Mr Fox and other stop animation then you'll love this too. Simple story well done.
A lovely visual story by Wes Anderson accompanied by a brilliant cast with an excellent soundtrack to back it.
Not love and affection. It is a stark political metaphor.

I love the animation and style. The plot is smooth, and it's very enjoyable. I don't know how people don't like it. It's a little weird at some parts, but it's a nice movie. In my personal opinion, it's a good movie with a heart-warmingly weird story

This film has art, entertainment, educational and literary values. Through the whole film this idea of conformism is presented through how the Japanese citizens all simply given to the mayors hate for dogs and conform. Other art values include the sound/audio techniques used in the film. Every voice and sound effect lines up perfectly with the kind of animation they used. Entertainment wise it didn't seem to be the most popular film that ever come out in theaters, but it was popular enough. Powerful scenes included whenever the Dog Chief or the main character Atari discovered something new having to do with Atari's dog and Chief's brother Spots. Those scenes seemed to add more excitement and interest in the film. A morale message that can be seen in the film is don't just conform to those in power and their ideas, think for yourself and what you believe is right. Scenes that reinforce this message are whenever Tracy Walker fights for the cause to save the dogs or stands up for what she believes is right. Internal conflict increases well in how Chief has pride in knowing that he must help Atari, but will not until a certain point. External conflict develops in the fight between the main good characters and society. Their will to bring back dogs is against what their society now traditionally believes in. All in all it was a wonderful Wes Anderson movie, some of his best work in my opinion and I think if I had watched this movie as a child I would've loved it even more.

Review title: Isle of Dogs - handsome, engaging, unique
Review_body: Bursting full to the brim of mouth watering visuals, stunning production and flawless stop motion animation, Isle of Dogs shines as one of the best animated films ever crafted technically, and possibly the best film by unique and stylised filmmaker Wes Anderson. The film executes an unexpectedly complex story somewhat well, although it doesn't really focus on a main protagonist. Characters like Atari and Koboyashi lack personality, not only due to the language barrier and Anderson's common blank slate characters but also because there is not enough time spent exploring them compared to other supporting roles. I felt if the film was even 10 minutes longer, we could have seen relationships thicken and characters explored more than they were, rather than devoting time to supporting characters who felt more like protagonists as well, thus making the film full of side characters and no focus. Despite this, "Isle of Dogs" still feels special, gorgeous, inspired and heart-warming. The dogs are likable and appealing, and every frame of the film feels as though all the care in the world has been put into it. The astonishing production team has to be commended. Every performance was well done, including the child actors. Although Isle of Dogs features a cute array of animals and a whimsical, childish appearance, it is certainly not a film for young children. With most of the engagement coming from the dialogue driven plot, and an overall dark tone with references to cannibalism, suicide, euthanisation and concentrated genocide - don't take your 7-year-old to this movie but do take your teen to see it. In conclusion, Isle of Dogs is a sweet, aesthetically driven, technical masterpiece which, while lacking in character depth and a consistent tone (like most Anderson flicks), is still a must watch for film lovers and teens and up alike.I would recommend Isle of Dogs.

Review title: Best film i have seen in a while
Review_body: I love films, i even like bad ones Unironically, but when you have a film were even cynical assholes think this film is great then you know your doing something right. I was never bored during the film and it was great that there was bearly any scenes were nothing was animated and all scenes contained no effects or cgi, all of it was practical in clever ways. The bad things in this film are very small and not very important but can bring something down. The twist were the main dog that they are looking for (spots) is found out to be the pack owners brother. The twist annoyed me but it would have been better if the main dog was spots because it would make out that this character that is tough and violent was a kig caring pet that forgot the luxury days of his life. Overall this was a fantastic film and would recommend to friends and family and people online

Isle of dogs is a masterpeice. It is now my favorite movie. Each scene is practical and carefully crafted. The story and visuals are outstanding. Its emotionally moving and charming. I definitely recommend this movie to anyone.

Review title: Wes Anderson's masterpiece since fantastic mr. fox
Review_body: I loved the premise of the movie, the stop motion animation looks fantastic in the trailer, and i believe that this movie is going to be A+, if this animation wont win the best animation feature in the academy awards, i'll wont follow the oscars event anymore

Review title: used the images but ignored the history
Review_body: I finally watched the hottest film, Isle of Dogs. And it made me confused and even so mad. Well, the film could be seen nicely directed with exotic images, if you don't have any background knowledge about imperialism period of the country, Japan.Although the movie explained its time setting as the future, it obviously borrowed the images from Japan in the imperialism and colonial period such as costumes, hair style, how the government controls the people and how they were controlled. And from the point of view as a Korean, a person from the colonial victim country, it's not just about the cute dogs.There is an isle called Gunkanjima which was called 'Isle of jail' by Korean people near a city of Japan, 'Nagasaki', just as there is the isle of dogs near a virtual city in the movie, 'Megasaki'. From 1940 to 1945, approximately 800 of Korean people were drafted into the coal mine which was filled with high temperature poisonous gas above 50C for compulsory labour. They were literally treated like 'dogs'. And 122 of them passed away in the 'isle of jail'. Moreover, Japanese government didn't inform most of the deaths even to their families.If you still can't understand why I feel so mad, I can explain it more easily by metaphor. Just imagine there's a movie which German people in the Nazis period style appear in, and they commit 'Dogs' to an isolated isle. It can't but remind of 'the place' where all we know.Freedom of expression should not be respected always but only when with responsibility. If Wes Anderson just picked the country and the city because it's his favorite as he said, he should have known enough and well. And I would blame on his ignorance. However, if not, I am really wondering what he wanted to say through the film.

Review title: An improvement on an already solid formula.
Review_body: Wes Anderson creates meticulously detailed worlds. This is true for all his films, but this one is specifically evident of this fact. Possibly the most "Wes Anderson" film I've ever seen, "Isle of Dogs" is in many ways a spiritual successor to "Fantastic Mr. Fox", the only difference being overall technical quality. "Isle of Dogs" takes the elements from Anderson's previous foray into animation; particularly stilted and short dialogue, whimsical sound design, solid comedic elements, and a vibrant array of color, and improves on every single one. It has enough lighthearted character to make it a genuinely enjoyable theatre-film, but also enough interesting shots and subtext to warrant a second viewing. Though I wouldn't recommend this to someone who doesn't already enjoy Wes Anderson's style, or to anyone under the age of 12 for fear that it would just go over their head... I had a great time watching this film, and would tell everyone else to go see this soon-to-be animated classic immediately.

Review title: If you don't know who Wes Anderson is, you're probably not going to like this
Review_body: Saw this mainly for the good reviews as the other options in the theatre weren't so good. Read the reviews and had no idea who Wes Anderson was and why people were raving as though he was some kind of movie God. The animation was pretty terrific and the story line was good altho you knew how it would mostly turn out. Humor was good. My 14 and 12 yo boys were quite bored. Mostly thought it was quite slow. Definitely more of an adult movie despite the main theme of a boy doing everything he can to reunite with his dog.

The animation is beautiful and the relationship between Atari and Chef is cute, the music is great and so is the character design and the world that has been created. The setting and characters are visually interesting. The pacing is good and the visual comedy is good. I didn't like how they split it into chapters, they didn't really need to do that and I feel like the narrator was unoriginal and I feel like they could have done something a bit more creative. Also the puffy girl character could have done more, because she didn't really do as much as she should have done in the amount of time that they gave her. That is basically everything I have to say about this movie, I think it is great and if you haven't seen it, then do see it. It is really enjoyable and I loved it, but this is not a kid's movie.

Review title: The bark was better than the bite
Review_body:
A Review of the Movie "Isle of Dogs"
by Banjo the Doberman (translated by Don Kurtz April 2018)(Note from the translator: listening to the original audio tapes of the early drafts of this essay one would only hear various yaps, rarphs, ruff (woof), bow wows et al. Thus the magic of having a human who understands SADB (Standard American Dog Bark)...oh that would be me...to bring this crisp content to non-canine moviegoers...virtually anyone. #sweartogod)Straight away I admit to mixing a cocktail of both regard and rebuke for Isle of Dogs (referred to hereafter as IOD to cool my boiling carpal tunnel).Doesn't that beg the question "What is this movie NOT about?" Decidedly not whale migrations, failed PHD theses, or the lack of a good crème brûlée in Oklahoma. And yet, in spite of the myriad topics not presented, the membrane (synonym for film) is an allegory. We posit good versus evil. Has that clash yet to receive a full treatment in any art or literature? That is question 6 on your homework assignment. So we have a megalomaniac running Megasaki - appropriate. He sends the infected dogs to quarantine on Trash Island. (Bakersfield with a lean shellac of animation.) Imagine conjoining "101 Dalmations" with "Schindler's List". All right don't. But when I think about IOD, mostly during the time I spend spinning in three circles before I lay (laid? lain?) on my Pendleton shirtish bucket by the fire (I know it's July but light it anyway), I face plot holes so substantial and off-white that no matter or radiation can escape. I scraped that from Wikipedia but it somehow works. Or doesn't. You decide. You can stop reading now. Go ahead I dare you. And I will scratch up some dirt on you and yours.Aside: somebody just came up to me, I'd been drowsing, and said "Where's the ball?" Really? So I am supposed to look keen and spirited? You know where the ball is. You pushed it under the couch. :end of aside.Just a few of the miscalculations from Wes Anderson and the other writers:-- How could a band of renegade pups not take a licking? Isn't that what they crave? Unto themselves and each other?
-- How fur can you go with the "Abused Dogs Stage Coup" device? 
-- Notice the cut-rate "Canine Ex Machina" in the trending1 "bucket on a wire" scene. (1Wes bought 1.5 million Twitter followers from Cambridge Analytica.)
-- Think on Rex, King, Duke, Boss, and Chief. Why didn't they flea when presented the opportunity?End of miscalculations.I don't want to kibble on small points but the leash I could do is scratch a hole in the new carpet. (There was something alive under the pad #sweartogod squirrel most likely). 
I discussed this for seven and a half hours with the other dogs on the block that comprise our karass. Our managers were all out "working". Right. So we talked and Gunner said that the one actress put the poo in poodle. Fair? Probably not. Other views held her to be fetching. Bear said that the mayor was so simple he should have been put into a witless protection program. My tenet was empathy for the mentality of the pack. Seeing them eat garbage reminded me of trying to find any watchable shows on DirecTV.Other principles we noted: inside every black dog is a white dog waiting to be shampooed and announced.I lift my leg and give IOD 4 Hydrants and a patch of grass. And I will now accept my chew toy.

Review title: Enjoyable, far from being the best work of W.AY
Review_body:
Anderson's narrative is not felt, unlike Fantastic fox the plot is locked and all its characters are not so interesting.
An admirable and beautiful work, however, Anderson forgets artistic ideas and prefers a simple story.

Review title: I love dogs, but this sucked
Review_body: I am reading through reviews and have no idea how people think this movie was worth watching. Luckily I have movie pass so this pile of excrement didn't get my money, or I'd have asked for it back from the box office. The movie is tediously slow with below average imagery and poor writing. You know exactly how the movie is going to go, and just don't care about it the whole time. I couldn't sit still in the theatre because all I wanted to do was leave, which half the theatre did already by the end of the movie so it wasn't just me. Please don't do a sequel.
Film kontolllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllllll

Review title: The best film of 2018 so far
Review_body:
I am a huge Wes Anderson fan, seeing as he is my favorite director of all time, so buying a ticket for this film was a no-brainer.
The only thing I'm gonna say is: see this right now. It's on Blu-Ray, so no excuses.

Movies nowadays are very high tech and require a lot of work. An example of this is the recent movie hit Avengers Infinity War, which took so much time just to make a part one as well as took many movie actors hours and hours of practice just to do one scene. Isle of dogs is different in the way that it uses clay figures and use animation to make them move which is a very unique way to film, that many directors just do not do. The thing about this movie is the art of its simplicity, especially in their storyline. The movie is basically all about Japanese people hating dogs because of a corrupt dictator from the cat army who decided to put a disease in a dog which spread fear into the people, giving him power to kick out all dogs. A young boy named Atari is not happy about this, so he decides to leave the country to find his servant dog who was with him during his injury. I love the Visual Design aka Mise en scéne of the movie. The actions are so well timed, the characters are simple yet beautiful,and even the storyline, although somewhat cliché, it doesn't take away the beauty and overall greatness of the movie.Isle of Dogs is unique in the way that even though the language is Japanese, and dubbed to English, there are still parts that are in Japanese. Mr. Anderson was very wise in this decision as those words that are in Japanese hold a very deep meaning that I'm dubbed, could make the viewers not fully grasp the intention of the words used. What it lacks however is that it doesn't fully develop the side characters as when Atari was in trash island, he met a dog and his squad, and after some character development, he gets close with the one dog that doesn't really like him, but after some time and some problems happen, and the other dogs are in danger, and released, their story ends there. The ending doesn't even reveal how they ended up. Basically, what I just stated was merely nitpicking and that didn't really affect my overall perspective on the movie, which is it is great. I actually enjoyed the movie from start to finish and I would definitely recommend other people to watch it if they have the opportunity to.

Review title: Isle of dogs, a unique movie in itself
Review_body: Isle of dogs is not your typical film. Sure it has some big name stars voice acting in the film, but the way they show it is different from what we have seen so far. They used clay and moved each of them part by part and used it for the film. Over all I liked the film because it is not something you see everyday. It is unique in its own way, some people might find it weird but some might be intrigued by it. The films cinematography is good in the sense that they do not jump to different places all of a sudden. The general plot of the story is also different and the sound is clear when watching. The film is mostly spoken in English or translated from Japanese. The dogs in the film all speak english while the humans in Japan obviously speak Japanese. Even when the people were talking, there were no subtitles provided in the film. I think this was done to sow the difference between humans and dogs. When we speak, dogs are unable to comprehend what we are saying. Same for us when dogs bark, we have no clue of their intention. This is because we are watching the film through a dogs perspective. They understand each other while they do not understand the people. This helped show how different dogs and man are even if dogs are called a "man's best friend".

The Isle Of Dogs has been a movie I've been exited to watch ever since I saw the trailer, and having the opportunity to watch it was really worth it. It has this sense of uniqueness amongst other animated films as it utilizes traditional Japanese puppets, utilizing it in modern methods. One things that stood out in the film is its, sound design. I feel as if every song or sound effect were utilized effectively and it really made me feel as if I were in the movie itself. The whistle the young boy plays, really struck me the most as it was repeated throughout the film and it really made a mark for itself as I've personally grown addicted to whistling it myself.I personally think the reason behind Wes Anderson's decision on not implementing subtitles for the Japanese parts is that it probably servers as an element of mystery for it is with this added element that prevents us from knowing what's gonna happen next. If the Japanese were to have subtitles, then we would be able to know everything completely hence Wes Anderson made it so that us, the viewers have to figure out and fix out pieces in this movie so that we will be able to fully comprehend what's happening.

Review title: Isle Of Dogs -- Brief Film Review
Review_body: I very much enjoyed watching the movie, Isle of Dogs, mainly because of the cinematography and visuals which were very unique and interesting. The way Anderson was able to use stop motion to his advantage and executing it perfectly to the smallest detail. This really caught my attention and was one of the main factors why I love this movie. The cinematography also made scenes more impactful especially those in which strong emotions like humor and anger are involved.Another thing that I found very interesting in the movie was the way Japanese was used. With a Western and English-speaking audience, it would be assumed that Japanese be subtitled by Anderson in order for viewers to understand what these lines mean, but then, to my surprise, he didn't. There must be a reason behind this, and I believe that this measure was done in order to make the audience think. Viewers are used to having information served onto them on a silver platter but then having un-subtitled Japanese forced viewers, forced me to pay attention to every single minor detail in order to use them as context clues to decipher the hieroglyphics that is Japanese. This really helped me appreciate the stop motion animation and the movie as a whole.

Wes Anderson's Isle of Dogs is a beautiful, well-made movie that stands out in its genre. Its setting is a gritty dystopian Japan in the future where dogs are all sent to an island as a way to quarantine a disease that has spread among them. The mayor of this dystopian world's son, whose dog was the first to be exiled, flies on a plane, but crashes on that island which has been overrun by the dogs. This boy, Atari Kobayashi, is then set on a path to find his lost dog.This movie has a very unique animation style that is different from other animated movies. It blends modern animation technology and stop-motion puppet animation. You can clearly see the effort put into the creation of the film. The movie itself is certainly more adult than most animated movies, however I believe that its PG-13 rating is fit for its type. Its own story is very unique, and its characters are developed very well. When watching the movie, I got attached to lots of the dogs, though of course I may be biased as a dog person. My favorite part of the story is how, despite its futuristic setting, many of its concepts can be seen in today's society, such as people being desensitized to many of the problems happening. Its soundtrack focuses on traditional Japanese music, which is very fitting to its setting.One major part of the movie is that most of the dialogue is spoken in Japanese. Aside from the foreigners in Japan, most people speak to each other in unsubtitled Japanese. The dogs, however, speak in English. A reason for this could be to show the movie in the perspective of the dogs, who cannot understand anything we say. In a way, it is Wes Anderson's way of making the viewers think like the dogs.Overall, Isle of Dogs is an amazingly made movie that excels in its genre and is able to provide a unique experience for all of its viewers. It is recommended for a more mature audience who would be able to see its themes and messages, but enjoy its style of animation and of course, its dogs.

This is an amazing movie. After Fantastic Mr Fox, I thought Wes Anderson was done with the medium of animation. I thought he couldn't make a comeback, because I hated Moonrise Kingdom and thought Grand Budapest Hotel wasn't his best movie. The great thing about this movie is that it doesn't rely on cliches. Most of Wes's films are comedies, but I find this one to be more of a drama. The untranslated Japanese offers actually made me connect MORE to the characters, because I can relate through more subtle means. This is a very subtle movie, so if you like blockbusters a lot, you'll probably hate this. The political allegory is very strong and relevant and capturing it through the lens of a 12 year old helps understand it from all point of view's. Atari's story has a happy ending, but the movie makes clear that the dog flu isn't the only political conspiracy in Japan. I loved all the characters, but Chief seemed to represent most a great character journey. He goes from being a stray, and hating humans, to starting to like Atari, to becoming his new dog at the end. It was a very interesting character journey, especially since Chief spoke in English. I loved the movie. Highly recommended

Before going into this movie I wasn't expecting anything out of the ordinary. Just a simple golden retriever in the frozen section at a local super market, so I thought. Little did I know this 97 minute film would change the course of my life. Seeing Chief for the first time made my knees go weak. Ever since my lord and savior, Bryan Cranston, played Hal Wilkerson in the early 2000s American sitcom, Malcom in the Middle,I knew he could turn any trash into treasure. Chief showed me true bravery. After being an active marine for 30 years I thought I knew what bravery was, but boy was I wrong. I think everyone can take some life lessons from this very close knit distopian Japanese community. Family always comes first. These pups showed loyalty in the most difficult of situations. If you are ever faced with such difficult situations just remember... what would Cheif do? 😌

Review title: Wes Anderson's best film since The Royal Tenenbaums!
Review_body: I was pleasantly surprised! And as a fan of his work, I have watched all of his movies- my favorite being The Royal Tenenbaums! However, not knowing what to expect when first watching Isle of Dogs, I must say that there is nothing about the movie I do not love! The characters, the screenplay, his very unique view and direction! Honestly, it reminds me a lot of The Royal Tenenbaums, but completely different and worth watching over and over! I quickly bought it and I have enjoyed each time I've watched it so far and counting!
